awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Developing Robust Longitudinal Indicators and Early Warnings of Cybercrime
awd_abstract_narration:
The proliferation of cybercrime has created an opportunity for researchers to study cybersecurity using a data-driven, and ultimately scientific, approach. This project seeks to improve the process of cybercrime data collection and analysis for the purpose of reducing its harm. Effort-based indicators, which measure the impact of defender actions such as the time taken to clean a compromised resource, are being constructed for use in analyzing data gathered on multiple categories of cybercrime. Indicators are being collected throughout the duration of the project in order to enable longitudinal analysis, for example, to measure any improvements that result from dissemination. It is also being investigated whether it is feasible to devise and deploy a prototype early-warning system that proactively alerts defenders quickly enough to arrest concentrated spikes in cybercriminal activity. The project's educational objective is to advance the science of cybersecurity by contributing public datasets of cybercriminal activity to be shared with other researchers and incorporated into curriculum modules. Instructional initiatives include improving existing curricula and publishing stand-alone resources that can be adopted by others.

The project is advancing understanding of how to construct reliable cybercrime indicators. Effort-based indicators help mitigate information asymmetries, so that anyone can see which defenders are working harder to clean up compromised resources. This could in turn improve the response to cybercrime overall by solving coordination problems in which individual defenders shirk responsibility. The project is also advancing understanding of how the response to cybercrime changes over time by collecting data for several years. If widely shared, the indicators can help incentivize defenders to fight cybercrime over the long term. The project seeks to identify not only how to construct the indicators, but also what is the most effective way to share them. The early-warning system, if successful, could greatly enhance the efficiency of countermeasures by helping defenders get ahead of the shifting tactics used by attackers. In the education program supported by the project, datasets are being added to curriculum modules that teach scientific approaches to cybersecurity. Modules are being designed for not only graduate and undergraduate degree programs, but also for middle and high school students, free online courses co-developed by the PI, and a security economics textbook under development.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to improve the process of cybercrime data collection and analysis for the purpose of reducing its harm. The project constructed and evaluated several types of cybercrime indicators to support empirical cybersecurity measurement efforts. The project advanced understanding of how to construct reliable cybercrime indicators by identifying both positive and negative results for multiple application domains.

The first area investigated was effort-based indicators related to web-based malware, specifically the time to remediate malware by hosting providers and webmasters. While significant variation in remediation times was observed, the variation was not found to be consistent across abuse datasets. Moreover, comparing summary statistics, such as the median time to remove malware per provider, could be misleading. These differences were caused primarily by the reduced availability of data when split by hosting provider combined with increased sensitivity to outliers.

Another area of focus that exhibited similar challenges was external measurement of enterprise networks. In this effort, data was gathered to count the number of open ports at enterprises, with a particular focus on services seen to be risky, such as Telnet, SMB and RDP. Additionally, data was gathered from HTTP headers at company websites that indicate the company has adopted security precautions (e.g., setting a Content Security Policy). Analysis revealed that once inspected at the level of the organization, these data become sparse, which limits their utility. Nonetheless, a case-control study was designed to evaluate whether firms that experienced ransomware incidents were more likely to improve their security posture (as measured by the presence of open ports and website security configurations). Analysis indicated that while the security posture improved for some companies, for many it did not, and it sometimes worsened. Moreover, no statistically significant difference was observed in how much behavior changed after experiencing ransomware compared to the control population.

The project made significant progress in providing empirically grounded loss distributions associated with multiple cybercrime categories. These loss distributions are important for rational risk management, and they are essential inputs to cyber investment models. Yet there are very few examples of reliable loss distributions in the literature. For business email compromise (BEC), data provided by the FBI IC3 was analyzed to report an empirical loss distribution for the first time. Additionally, a novel method was devised to estimate an inferred distribution for cyber losses using publicly reported cyber insurance premiums.

Finally, the project developed methods to identify the malicious registration of domain names to visually impersonate enterprises. These domains have been shown to support BEC, which is the most significant form of cybercrime (in terms of financial losses) over the past decade. The project measured, for the first time, a floor for the extent to which enterprises have been targeted (at least 7%). The research spans the period 2009-2022, enabling longitudinal analysis of attack prevalence and defender response over a very long period.

Three attack methods were investigated. Character doppelgangers, in which attackers register domain names that are visually similar to legitimate businesses (e.g., firrn.com impersonating firm.com), were observed in 21,192 attack domains.   First-party doppelgangers, in which enterprises are impersonated by registering lookalike subdomains of enterprise websites (e.g., mail-firm.com impersonating mail.firm.com), were observed in 84,952 attack domains. Third-party doppelgangers, in which enterprises are impersonated by registering lookalike subdomains of legitimate third-party online service providers (e.g., firm-sharepoint.com impersonating firm.sharepoint.com), were observed in 5,448 attack domains.

Strong empirical evidence was collected that reinforces prior results that cybercriminal actors often follow an "iterated weakest link" strategy. In this case, attackers abused a single registrar for the bulk of malicious registrations for several years. Once that defender clamped down, the attackers quickly adapted by moving onto new targets, quickly reaching similar aggregate attack numbers for more than a year. After repeated interventions, however, attack prevalence eventually diminished.

The project has enabled significant educational and broader societal impacts. Modules for interacting with cybersecurity datasets have been developed and utilized in graduate-level courses in security economics. A free online course on security economics, including cybersecurity measurement modules that incorporate lessons learned from this project, has been co-developed by the PI and collaborators. A winter school on quantitative information security research for aspiring PhD researchers was launched by the PI and collaborators and has now successfully run three times. The project's goal of advancing the science of cybersecurity was reflected in the PI's effort to establish a new interdisciplinary academic unit in cyber studies comprised of computer scientists, engineers and social scientists.


Last Modified: 10/29/2023
Modified by: Tyler Moore
